contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=May 2013}} [[Image:Location of Yingde within Guangdong (China).png|300px|thumb|Yingde City (red) within Guangdong]] '''Yingde''' ([[Chinese Postal Map Romanisation]]: '''Yingtak'''; {{lang-zh|英德}}) is a historical city in the north of [[Guangdong]] Province, [[People's Republic of China|China]]. The city is on the [[Beijiang River]], a tributary of the [[Pearl River (China)|Pearl River]]. Administratively, it is part of the [[Qingyuan, Guangdong|Qingyuan]] [[prefecture-level city]]. The principal languages are [[Yue Chinese|Cantonese]] and [[Hakka (language)|Hakka]]. [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]] is rarely spoken except in teaching. It is famous for its [[Yingde Stone]] and [[Ying De Hong]] tea. In 1963 the British royal family popularized Yingde's black tea worldwide after offering the tea to guests at the Queen's Banquet.<ref>http://www.thatsmags.com/prd/article/view/14007</ref> Yingde's tea history dates back to over 1,200 years ago. It is considered to be one of the top three places in the world to grow black tea.<ref>http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/m/qingyuan/2010-12/23/content_11746305.htm</ref> ==See also== *[[Ying De Hong]] {{County-level divisions of Guangdong}} {{coord|24|10|N|113|25|E|display=title|region:CN_type:city_source:GNS-enwiki}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Cities in Guangdong]] {{Guangdong-geo-stub}}
